channel.title: swap - swap file - Whonix-Gateway freezing during apt-get dist-upgrade - encrypted swap-file-creator
channel.description:
Whonix-Gateway default RAM is currently set to 768 MB. (Whonix-Workstation default RAM is currently set to 2048 MB.)
During upgrade Whonix-Gateway freezes. Not totally. But it looks frozen. The seconds on the clock stay at the same number for several minutes. This happens during module building (VirtualBox guest additions) as well as kernel header package upgrade. During that time, Tor running on Whonix-Gateway is not accessible from Whonix-Workstation.
Hence, I plan to re-vitalize swap-file-creator. I couldn't find out why it was previously removed from installation by default. Once swap-file-creator is running, this issue is gone. (A small [fix](https://github.com/Whonix/swap-file-creator/commit/8191bd1486518541ce2b7cbdefa200b4a5411dc9) for buster was required.)
This is about Non-Qubes-Whonix only since Qubes-Whonix has dynamic RAM assignment (and higher system requirements).
Could you please review / improve this line? @HulaHoop
cryptsetup --batch-mode --hash sha512 -c aes-xts-plain64 --key-size 512 luksFormat
https://github.com/Whonix/swap-file-creator/blob/master/usr/share/swap-file-creator/common#L97
----

item.title: swap - swap file - Whonix-Gateway freezing during apt-get dist-upgrade - encrypted swap-file-creator
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/Whonix/swap-file-creator

if there is ENOUGH_RAM (defaults to 1950 MB) ("2 GB"), do not create a swapfile

by adrelanos on 11:34AM - 24 Oct 19 UTC
changed 2 files with 7 additions and 0 deletions.
github.com/Whonix/swap-file-creator

fix enough RAM logic

by adrelanos on 11:51AM - 24 Oct 19 UTC
changed 1 files with 1 additions and 1 deletions.

In effect,

  • no swap file will be created by default in Whonix-Workstation (since it has 2 GB RAM).
  • But in Whonix-Gateway would create a swapfile (since default 768 MB RAM). - Unless the user gives Whonix-Gateway 2 GB RAM manually.
HulaHoop:

Alright I guess this doesn’t affect live mode since everything is redirected to RAM including the swap file.

Disabled in live mode already (but in theoretic case that was broken, then yes). I guess. Location of swapfile is /var/swapfile.

github.com

Whonix/swap-file-creator/blob/master/usr/share/swap-file-creator/start#L95

    

  1.    chmod --recursive 0600 "$MAPPER_FULL"
    2. 

  2. 

    3. 

  3.    mkswap --force --uuid "$UUID" "$MAPPER_FULL" $MKSWAP_EXTRA >/dev/null
    4. 

  4.    swapon "$MAPPER_FULL" $SWAPON_EXTRA
    5. 

  5. 

    6. 

  6.    rm --force "$RUN_FOLDER/progress"
    7. 

  7.    touch "$RUN_FOLDER/success"
    8. 

  8.    return 0
    9. 

  9. }
    10. 

  10. 

    11. 

  11. if cat /proc/cmdline | grep "boot=live" ; then
    12. 

  12.    echo "Live mode detected. Swap file creation skipped."
    13. 

  13.    exit 0
    14. 

  14. fi
    15. 

  15. 

    16. 

  16. do_start
    17.
HulaHoop:

Question is if this would push current RAM reqs way higher than it is now vs increasing GW RAM without adding a swap file.

Why would adding a swap file increase GW RAM requirements? Perhaps I got that wrong.

I don’t like swap / swapfile since use of these can make the system super slow but it seems necessary. Also therefore, related, swappiness kernel setting is set to lowest:

github.com

Whonix/swappiness-lowest/blob/master/etc/sysctl.d/swappiness-lowest.conf

## Copyright (C) 2012 - 2018 ENCRYPTED SUPPORT LP <adrelanos@riseup.net>
## See the file COPYING for copying conditions.

## Let the kernel only swap if it is absolutely necessary.
## Better not be set to zero:
## - https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/6/html/Performance_Tuning_Guide/s-memory-tunables.html
## - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swappiness
vm.swappiness=1
HulaHoop:

Since we don’t care about memorizing passphrases here just use a randomly generated character string.

Indeed. However, anti-forensics cannot be guaranteed due to the same reasons listed on https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Encrypted_Images.
